docs.text:
Fiddler is a stream processor built in rust that uses a yaml based configuration file syntax to map together inputs, processors, and outputs. Fiddler takes a module approach to inputs, processors, and outputs allowing users to take advantage of incremental releases of new modules or develop their own to run within the fiddler runtime. Whether you are looking to utilize fiddler for it's processing capabilities through the CLI or integrate directly in your own applications, head over to our Documentation to get started.

See our Getting Started to begin!

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text:
label: Label for Pipeline
num_threads: 3
input:
  label: standard in
  stdin: {}
processors:
  - noop: {}
  - label: Split lines
    lines: {}
output:
  label: standard out
  std: out

docs.title: label
docs.text: Descriptive label for the component. (Pipeline, Input, Processor, Output) Type: string Required: false

docs.title: num_threads
docs.text: Number of processor and output threads to spawn in the pipeline Type: int Required: false [Default: number of CPUs]

docs.title: input
docs.text: Valid input configuration. See Inputs Type: object Required: true

docs.title: processors
docs.text: An Array of processors to perform manipulation of messages. See Processors Type: array Required: true

docs.title: output
docs.text: Valid output configuration. See Outputs Type: string Required: true

docs.title: Environmental Variables
docs.text:
Fiddler supports handlebars style templating and will replace values of configuration files with available environmental varialbes. This is useful for dynamic or sensitive values; such as URLs and passowrds. For example: 

output:
  elasticsearch:
    url: {{ ES_URL }}
    username: elastic
    password: {{ ES_PASS }}
    index: flow
    cert_validation: None
    batching_policy:
      size: 100
      duration: 10s

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Grab a release for your OS here
  2. Install with Cargo cargo install fiddler
  3. Build with Cargo cargo build --release --features all

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage: fiddler <COMMAND>

Commands:
  lint  Data Stream processor CLI written in rust
  run   Data Stream processor CLI written in rust
  test  Data Stream processor CLI written in rust
  help  Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -h, --help  Print help

docs.title: Run
docs.text:
Data Stream processor CLI written in rust

Usage: fiddler run [OPTIONS]

Options:
  -c, --config <CONFIG>
  -l, --log-level <LOG_LEVEL>  [default: none] [possible values: info, debug, trace, error, none]
  -h, --help                   Print help
  -V, --version                Print version
  1. fiddler run -c <path_to_config_file> [ -c ... ]

docs.title: Lint
docs.text:
Data Stream processor CLI written in rust

Usage: fiddler lint [OPTIONS]

Options:
  -c, --config <CONFIG>
  -h, --help             Print help
  -V, --version          Print version
  1. fiddler lint -c <path_to_config_file> [ -c ... ]

docs.title: Test
docs.text:
Data Stream processor CLI written in rust

Usage: fiddler test [OPTIONS]

Options:
  -c, --config <CONFIG>
  -l, --log-level <LOG_LEVEL>  [default: none] [possible values: info, debug, trace, error, none]
  -h, --help                   Print help
  -V, --version                Print version

Tests within fiddler are designed to test the processing pipeline configuration. The expected naming syntax is <filename>_test.yaml. I.e. if you have a configuration input.yaml. The expected filename is input_test.yaml.

The test file syntax is as follows: 

- name: name_of_test
  inputs:
   - list of expected input strings
  expected_outputs:
   - list of expected output strings

For example: 

- name: input_test
  inputs:
    - Hello World
  expected_outputs: 
    - Hello World

  1. fiddler-cli test -c <path_to_configuration>.yaml

docs.title: Building own CLI with Additional modules
docs.text:
Creating your own fiddler-cli requires a binary crate with at least two dependencies, fiddler_cmd and fiddler.

cargo new my-cli --bin cargo add fiddler cargo add fiddler_cmd

Next create your runtime, by default in src/main.rs 

use fiddler_cmd::run;
use fiddler::Error;
use fiddler::config::{ConfigSpec, register_plugin};

#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> Result<(), Error> {
    // insert registration of custom modules here
    register_plugin("mock".into(), ItemType::Input, conf_spec, create_mock_input)?;

    // run the normal CLI
    run().await
}

docs.title: Integrating the runtme into your own application
docs.text: Head on over to docs.rs to view the latest API reference for utilizing fiddler runtime.

docs.title: Input
docs.text:
The source of messages for fiddler are described as inputs. There may only be one input per configuration item. Input key names must be uniquely registered across all available fiddler inputs.

input:
  label: standard in
  stdin: {}

docs.title: aws_s3
docs.text:
Process data from a S3 Bucket

RequiredFull 
input:
    aws_s3:
        bucket: "my-bucket"

input:
    aws_s3:
        bucket: "my-bucket"
        prefix: "myprefix/"
        queue:
            queue_url: "https://some_queue_url"
            endpoint_url: "https://some_unique_endpoint"
            credentials:
                access_key_id: "AccessKey"
                secret_access_key: "SecretKey"
                session_token: "SessionToken"
            region: "us-west-2"
        credentials:
            access_key_id: "AccessKey"
            secret_access_key: "SecretKey"
            session_token: "SessionToken"
        delete_after_read: false
        endpoint_url: "https://some_unique_endpoint"
        read_lines: true
        force_path_style_urls: false
        region: us-east-1

docs.title: Metadata
docs.text: s3_bucket: S3 Bucket of the object s3_key: S3 Key

docs.title: bucket
docs.text: The S3 Bucket to process. Note: if queue is provided, the bucket provided in the S3 Event Record will be used Type: string Required: true

docs.title: prefix
docs.text: The prefix of the objects from the s3 bucket to process. Note: ignored if queue is used Type: string Required: false

docs.title: queue
docs.text:
The aws_sqs object to utilize. Expectes S3 Notifications directly to SQS Type: object Required: false Properties: queue_url         AWS SQS Queue URL to utilize         Type: string         Required: true

endpoint_url         Custom AWS SQS Endpoint URL         Type: string         Required: false

credentials         AWS Credentials Object to utilize. If no credentials object is provided, fiddler will utilize standard SDK locations to pull in credentials.         Type: object         Properties: access_key_id                 AWS Access Key ID                 Type: string                 Required: true secret_access_key                 AWS Secret Access Key                 Type: string                 Required: true session_token                 AWS Session Token                 Type: string                 Required: false         Required: false

docs.title: credentials
docs.text: AWS Credentials Object to utilize. If no credentials object is provided, fiddler will utilize standard SDK locations to pull in credentials. Type: object Properties: access_key_id         AWS Access Key ID         Type: string         Required: true secret_access_key         AWS Secret Access Key         Type: string         Required: true session_token         AWS Session Token         Type: string         Required: false Required: false

docs.title: delete_after_read
docs.text: Delete the object after it has been fully processed Type: bolean Default: false Required: false

docs.title: force_path_style_urls
docs.text: Force Path Style S3 URLS Type: boolean Required: false

docs.title: region
docs.text: AWS Region of the bucket Type: string Required: false

docs.title: Credentials
docs.text:
Required IAM permissions to operate: - s3:GetObject - s3:ListBucket

Required IAM permissions to operate if using the Queue: - sqs:ReceiveMessage - sqs:DeleteMessage - sqs:ChangeMessageVisibility

Required IAM permissions to operate if using delete_objects - s3:DeleteObject

If using KMS, the following kms permissions may be needed on the relvant keys: - kms:Decrypt

docs.title: aws_sqs
docs.text:
Receive messages from an AWS SQS Queue

RequiredFull 
input:
    aws_sqs:
        queue_url: "https://some_queue_url"

input:
    aws_sqs:
        queue_url: "https://some_queue_url"
        endpoint_url: "https://some_unique_endpoint"
        credentials:
            access_key_id: "AccessKey"
            secret_access_key: "SecretKey"
            session_token: "SessionToken"
        region: "us-west-2"

docs.title: Metadata
docs.text: All SQS Message attributes are inserted into metadata of the message

docs.title: queue_url
docs.text: AWS SQS Queue URL to utilize Type: string Required: true

docs.title: endpoint_url
docs.text: Custom AWS SQS Endpoint URL Type: string Required: false

docs.title: credentials
docs.text: AWS Credentials Object to utilize. If no credentials object is provided, fiddler will utilize standard SDK locations to pull in credentials. Type: object Properties: access_key_id         AWS Access Key ID         Type: string         Required: true secret_access_key         AWS Secret Access Key         Type: string         Required: true session_token         AWS Session Token         Type: string         Required: false Required: false

docs.title: Credentials
docs.text: Required IAM permissions to operate: - sqs:ReceiveMessage - sqs:DeleteMessage - sqs:ChangeMessageVisibility

docs.title: file
docs.text:
Receive messages from an AWS SQS Queue

RequiredFull 
input:
    file:
        filename: path_to_file

input:
    file:
        filename: path_to_file
        codec: Tail
        position_filename: path_to_position_file

docs.title: filename
docs.text: Path to the file to consume Type: string Required: true

docs.title: codec
docs.text: Enum to outline the type of file reader to implement Type: string Accepted values: Lines: Read the file line by line [default] ToEnd: Read the file in its entirity Tail: Read the file line by line, waiting for new data to be written

docs.title: position_filename
docs.text: Filename to track the position of tailed files Type: string Required: with codec: Tail

docs.title: stdin
docs.text:
Read data from stdin by lines and forward to the pipeline

Required 
input:
    stdin: {}

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
The sinks of fiddler are described as outputs. There may only be one output per configuration item. Output key names must be uniquely registered across all available fiddler outputs.

output:
  label: standard out
  stdout: {}

docs.title: aws_sqs
docs.text:
Send messages to an AWS SQS Queue

RequiredFull 
output:
    aws_sqs:
        queue_url: "https://some_queue_url"

output:
    aws_sqs:
        queue_url: "https://some_queue_url"
        endpoint_url: "https://some_unique_endpoint"
        credentials:
            access_key_id: "AccessKey"
            secret_access_key: "SecretKey"
            session_token: "SessionToken"
        region: "us-west-2"

docs.title: queue_url
docs.text: AWS SQS Queue URL to utilize Type: string Required: true

docs.title: endpoint_url
docs.text: Custom AWS SQS Endpoint URL Type: string Required: false

docs.title: credentials
docs.text: AWS Credentials Object to utilize. If no credentials object is provided, fiddler will utilize standard SDK locations to pull in credentials. Type: object Properties: access_key_id         AWS Access Key ID         Type: string         Required: true secret_access_key         AWS Secret Access Key         Type: string         Required: true session_token         AWS Session Token         Type: string         Required: false Required: false

docs.title: Credentials
docs.text: Required IAM permissions to operate: - sqs:SendMessage

docs.title: drop
docs.text:
Discard messages sent to this output

Required 
output:
    drop: {}

docs.title: elasticsearch
docs.text:
Receive messages from an AWS SQS Queue

RequiredFull 
output:
    elasticsearch:
        url: https://127.0.0.1:9200
        index: my_index

output:
    elasticsearch:
        url: https://127.0.0.1:9200
        username: elastic
        password: changeme
        cloud_id: someId
        index: my_index
        cert_validation: Default

docs.title: url
docs.text: Elasticsearch URL to utilize Type: string Required: true

docs.title: username
docs.text: Elasticsearch username to use Type: string Required: false.

docs.title: password
docs.text: Password for the elasticsearch user Type: string Required: false

docs.title: cloud_id
docs.text: Elasticsearch CloudID Type: string Required: false.

docs.title: index
docs.text: Elasticsearch index to utilize. default behavior is to append YYYY-MM-DD to the index name. i.e. index of index would send to index-YYYY-MM-DD where the date chosen is the date of ingest. Type: string Required: true

docs.title: cert_validation
docs.text: Enum to identify which type of certification validation is utilized Type: string AcceptedValues: Default: default mechanisms utilized by elasticsearch's SDK [default] None: Do not perform certification validation Required: false

docs.title: stdout
docs.text:
Emit process messages to stdout

Required 
output:
    stdout: {}

docs.title: switch
docs.text:
Switch accepts an array of valid outputs and is expected to be utlized with the check output. Switch will attempt each provided output; while failing to the next provided the error is returned is ConditionalCheckfailed. Other encountered errors will be surfaced.

Required 
output:
  switch: []

docs.title: check
docs.text:
Required 
output:
  switch:
    - check:
        condition: '\"Hello World\" > `5`'
        output: 
          stdout: {}"

docs.title: condition
docs.text: Condition utilized for the execution of the output step utilizing jmespath syntax for evaluation. As such, this can only be utilized with JSON documents. Type: string Required: true

docs.title: output
docs.text: Valid fiddler output module Type: object Required: true

docs.title: Processors
docs.text:
Processors in fiddler handle all of the data transformation operations on the messages received from Inputs. Each Processor receives a single Message and is expected to return one to many messages as a result. Each result is forward along to processors later in the array; or to the desired output.

processors:
  - label: lines
    lines: {}
  - label: noop
    noop: {}
  - label: pretty print
    python:
      string: true
      code: |
        import json
        root = json.dumps(json.loads(root), indent=4)

docs.title: compress
docs.text:
Compress the message being processed

RequiredFull 
processors:
    - compress: {}

processors:
    - compress: 
        algorithm: Gzip

docs.title: algorithm
docs.text: The compression algorithm to use. [Default: Gzip] Type: string Required: false Accepted values: Gzip: compress the message using gzip. Zip: compress the message using deflate Zlib: compress the message using zlib

docs.title: decode
docs.text:
Decode the message

RequiredFull 
processors:
    - decode: {}

processors:
    - decode: 
        algorithm: Base64

docs.title: algorithm
docs.text: The decoding algorithm to use. [Default: Base64] Type: string Required: false Accepted values: Base64: decode the message as base64

docs.title: decompress
docs.text:
Decompress the message being processed

RequiredFull 
processors:
    - decompress: {}

processors:
    - decompress: 
        algorithm: Gzip

docs.title: algorithm
docs.text: The compression algorithm to use. [Default: Gzip] Type: string Required: false Accepted values: Gzip: decode the message as base64 Zip: decode the message as base64 Zlib: decode the message as base64

docs.title: lines
docs.text:
Split the received message into multiple messages separated by lines

Required 
processors:
    - lines: {}

docs.title: noop
docs.text:
performs no operation against the message

Required 
processors:
    - noop: {}

docs.title: python
docs.text:
Python is the primary source of inline message manipulation provided by Fiddler. Any third party packages utilized in Python will have to be installed on the OS running fiddler.

RequiredFull 
processors:
    - python:
        code: |
            new_string = \"python rules\"
            root = new_string

processors:
    - python:
        string: true
        code: |
            import json
            new_string = f\"python: {root}\"
            root = new_string

docs.title: string
docs.text: Indicate whether or not fiddler should convert the message to a string before invoking the python code. Type: string Required: false [default: false]

docs.title: code
docs.text: The python code to execute Type: string Required: true

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: The message is passed into the python code using a local variable root. The output taken from the executed code is also taken from the local variable root. By default root is bytes of the message, unless the argument string: true is proved, in which case root is converted to a string.

docs.title: switch
docs.text:
Switch accepts an array of valid processors and is expected to be utlized with the check output. Switch will attempt each provided processor; while failing to the next provided the error is returned is ConditionalCheckfailed. Other encountered errors will be surfaced.

Required 
processors:
  - switch: []

docs.title: check
docs.text:
Required 
processors:
  - switch:
      - check:
          condition: '\"Hello World\" > `5`'
          processors: 
            - noop: {}"

docs.title: condition
docs.text: Condition utilized for the execution of the processing step utilizing jmespath syntax for evaluation. As such, this can only be utilized with JSON documents. Type: string Required: true

docs.title: output
docs.text: Valid fiddler output module Type: object Required: true
